Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a New 500 MHz NMR Console and Accessories to Support Research and Education at Carnegie Mellon University
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program Professor Roberto Gil from Carnegie Mellon University will acquire a console for a 500 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer. The upgrade would consist of an ultra-fast and fully digital console, three new 500 MHz NMR broadband probes with digital tuning, a pre-cooling and stabilization accessory for ultra-precise temperature control from near ambient conditions down to 0 degrees C, and an automatic sample changer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas of study such as characterization of polymers and material chemistry, atom transfer radical polymerization, nucleic acid research and technology, and organic, inorganic and bioinorganic and biorganic chemistry as well as atmospheric and development of NMR methodologies, studies of small organic molecules in anisotropic media and molecular biosensors.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is arguably one of the most powerful analytical techniques available to Chemists. An NMR instrument is an essential piece of equipment for any Chemistry Department. Based on demand and department size, the number of instruments in Chemistry Departments around the world ranges from one to ten. An NMR instrument is not different from a radio station in which instead of listening to news and music, Chemists can tune to resonance frequencies of different elements such as hydrogen, carbon, phosphorous, fluorine, nitrogen, silicon, among others. Hence one can observe their presence in different type of chemical compounds and materials. Polymers (plastics), small molecules, nanoparticles, biomolecules, etc, can be identified and characterized using NMR. Without access to NMR it would be almost impossible for our Chemist to pursue their research projects. Our NMR Facility was created in July 2003 with two NMR instruments of 300 and 500 MHz of resonance frequency for hydrogens. The electronics of our 500 MHz instrument became obsolete and the funds received by NSF through the Major Research Instrumentation grant enabled us to upgrade it to a state-of-the-art new fully digital console, together with a robotic sample changer for 60 samples, a pre-cooling unit for precise temperature control and three additional multinuclear probes. This instrument is not only used to support research and education at the Chemistry Department. It is also open to CMU spin-off companies and another local company that supported the grant application. 

The new instrumentation has been intensively used by undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and visiting scholars from the research groups of the 14 majors users from our Department of Chemistry  in the areas of Polymers and Material Chemistry, Nucleic Acids Research and Technology, Atmospheric Chemistry, In Vivo Imaging Platform for Tracking Immunotherapeutic Cells, NMR Spectroscopy of Small Organic Molecules in Anisotropic Media, Molecular Biosensors, Nanotechnology, Green Oxidation Chemistry, Catalysis, Renewable Energy. During the award period, 17 peer-reviewed publications in high level scientific journals were generated.  With the current volume of demand for NMR time from our major users, we expect many more publications in the near future.

The addition of a robotic sample changer in combination with multinuclear probes featuring automatic tuning and matching makes the use of the 500 MHz instrument extremely efficient and friendly. The pre-cooling unit BCU-05 delivers superb temperature stability. The ability of queuing a series of samples and running multinuclear experiments on each of them in automation mode at nights and weekends is priceless.

Regarding the broader impact of this project, the current proposal involves the participation of 16 major users (including the PI), 10 senior researchers, 20 postdocs, 71 graduate students, three Carnegie Mellon spin-off companies and one small local company. Collectively, the supported companies have a total of 108 employees. In addition, two courses with a total enrollment of c.a. 56 students have received the benefits of this major upgrade. The upgrade also created a much friendlier environment for users with disabilities. 

We are really grateful to the National Science Foundation for this award since it changed the way NMR analysis is done at our site.
